column4: Does anyone know how to save my current Ubuntu Feisty installation in a some sort of disk image? I would like to try a Gutsy installation, and if I get errors or I'm not able to configure all the options for my laptop on it, get back to my current OS. Any idea?
so long as you save your home directory, the rest isn't very important

thanks, I can make a copy of /home directory, but I've configured many other things, like kernel boot options (specifical of my laptop), and I would like to preserve all these options if I can't configure all of them in Gutsy. I heard about 'ghost', but not sure if that would be helpful

oh.   if you boot a SysRescCd or similar live cd distro, you can mount your partitions and backup the information from them.  You can just do a full gzip compressed disk image, a tarball, or whatever.  Tar at least knows how to preserve file permissions if you tell it to
the functionally easy way to do this is borrow a spare hard disk
I have a 250 Gb external disk, but I would like to go back to my previous system using some kind of wizard, and seems that partimage can do this...
oh, "wizard" hmm.  don't know of any
you know what I mean... Next -> Next -> Finish :)
I just memorized some commands, I do this all the time.  Too lazy for GUI

I'm too lazy for commands :) well, really what I want is a process that configure Grub in a correct way, and restore the system. I'm not sure I'm able to do this only making a copy of the files in my linux partition

there's nothing too special about a linux setup. Files with permissions on ext3 filesystem, sockets, device nodes. Then you want to have some way to chroot into that after restoring the data and run grub to install it to the MBR
really though, borrow somebody's hard disk and install to that, if you are doing this for work
I don't have the expertise in this kind of things... MBR and so on
if you can figure out how to boot a SysRescCD and talk to me via IRC using irssi client on it, then I won't mind to walk you through the process in privmsg
thanks, I can't do this right now, but I have copy/pasted your previous message :)
and this is not for work... in fact, my job encourages me to use Windows, but I really want to use Ubuntu with VirtualBox (as I need to use Visual Studio)
